physDesc.p: Five pages typewritten in black ink. Archival notes read "(Ezra)" in pencil at the top of first page. Several handwritten changes to the text throughout the letter. Amy Lowell's address is given as: MISS A. LOWELL HEATH STREET BROOKLINE, MASS. BROOKLINE, MASS. Unsigned. Includes a postscript.

editorialDecl.p: This letter contains references to the following:

body.p: I think your scheme of a quarterly is really better than taking over "The Egoist." I don’t feel myself very much in sympathy with "The Egoist" as it has been run, as you must be aware from my letter, and the change of policy would probably lose their its present public, without the certainty of gaining a new one.

On the other hand, a new paper has the advantage of having everything to make or lose, without prejudice either way, which attracts me very much more. It has always been supposed that quarterlies would not go on this side of the water, and I am inclined to think that one would have to trust mostly to one’s English audience. I think, however, that if four first-class numbers could be brought out a year, by first-class people, that the magazine would soon gain a reputation.

In some ways a quarterly is more difficult to manage than a fortnightly or monthly, because
you cannot speak about current events in the same way, and it is more difficult to gain an audience for disconnected articles. But we can talk all this over when I am in London.

I am very anxious to have something done, because I find myself completely isolated over here, and although the magazines are very good, and print me, there is nothing that really sympathizes with me, or my objects. I feel that to gain the recognition I deserve, it will be necessary to create a public which shall no longer be bound by the Victorian tradition. That can be done, and done fairly quickly, I think, if one can only get an ear.
I don’t know who Joyce is. You say he and Lawrence are the best among the younger men. I quite agree with you as to Lawrence, but I never heard of Joyce. What did he write, and who is he?

I don’t believe that there is much use in reprinting pages from French books, nor do I think that you can expect help from the French departments of the universities, or the Alliance Française. All the libraries have the French periodicals, and by the people who care for French, they are universally read. I think if we wish to have
a French section, we must take our things first hand, as though we were merely another French review. We shall be bought by the libraries and universities on our own merits, and not because we are a rehash of what has already appeared in other books or magazines. The great difficulty in the periodical wouldwill be taking a happy medium and not using either extreme of contributorsarticles. With the preeminently "bourgeois," of course, we wish to have nothing to do; Bbut there is a fantastic extreme also! Which I think is what wrecked the editor of "The Smart Set" as a paying proposition.

I will make all inquiries I can, and do everything in my power, to find out what sales we might make, and what we could do by way of American contributors, and come over primed, in July. I am not coming solely for the sake of the magazine. I am coming on the principle that a boat goes into the dry dock to have its keep scraped.

I had a very nice letter indeed from Yeats the other day, the second I have had from him,
saying that he was returning to England, and, unfortunately, had had no Boston lectures. I tried to get him one from my brother, but he said that the schedule was already made up for this year, and they had no time left. I regretted very much losing the pleasure of having him at my house. He wrote me very pleasant things about your marriage, and told me more than you have ever done, You Secretive Feline!.

I enclose a little token of good will<del type="strikethrough>, in the form of a wedding present. Abyssinia, as you know, contains little but elephant’s tusks and barbarians. Therefore I am going to ask you to buy your own wedding present with the draft I enclose, in order that you may get something that you really want. It carries with it the best possible wishes to you and Miss Shakespeare.

I liked some of your things in "Poetry and Drama" very much indeed, particularly your spring crocuses, and your Faun. You are extremely good in "L’Ironie de Société," if I may coin such a kind of verse.

Harriet’s has printed a lot of me in the April number, as you will see. You may like the "Vers Libre" ones. The first two poems you know. The last one
I feel quite sure you will dislike extremely. It is what I might call "semi-Fort." Only "semi", I have done better work in that medium. Don’t mix it up with a semaphore; I am afraid it has no such telegraphic quality.
When you get through your honey-moon, let me know how you feel about some more stuff for "The Egoist," to be published before October. aAnd for the moment, gGoodby.
body.postscript: P.S. How is Fletcher, I wrote to him, congratulating him on the looks of his things in "The Egoist," and I have not heard from him for ages. It is my fault, for I didn’t answer his letter for a long time. I hope he is all right, for behe worries me a bit, he seemed so irrevocably tired last Autumn.
